div.l: For ielous folk ben perlous euermoo
Algate they wolde ther wyfes wende so
And for she was somdel smoterlich
She was a deynous as water in a dich
As ful of hoker and of bismariebismariebismare
She thouȝt that a Lady shuld hir spare
What for hir kynrede and her Nortelrie
That she had lerned in the Nonnerie
A dbouȝter bouȝterdouȝter he had born atwen̄ hem tuo
Of twenti yere withouten̄ any mo
Sauing a child that was of half yere age
In cradell it lay and was a propre page
This wenche and wel I growe was
With camuse nose ⁊and yhen greye as glas
With buttokkys brode ⁊and brestes rounde ⁊and hiȝe
But riȝt faire was hir heer I wil nat lye
The Person of the toun for she was so faire
In purpos was to make hir his ayre
Bothe of his catell and his mesuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
His purpos was to be stowe hir highe
Into som worthi blood of Auncestrie
For holi chirche good mot be dispended
On holi chirche blood that is descended
Therfore he wold his holi blood honoure
Thouȝ that hooli chirche he shuld deuoure
Gret sooken hath this Millere out of doute
With whete ⁊and malt of al the land aboute
And namely ther was a gret Collegge
Men clepe the Soler halle at Cambrigge
Ther was her whete ⁊and her malt eke I grounde
And on a day it hapned on a stounde
Syke lay the Manciple on̄ a maladye
Men wend wistly that he shuld deye
Fro wich this Miller stall bothe mele ⁊and corn̄
An C tymes more than beforn̄
For ther beforn he stall full curteisly
But now he was a fooll outrageously
For wich the wardein chid and made fare
But therof the Millere set nat a tare
He craked bost and swoor it was nat so
Than were there young scolers tuo
That duelten̄ in the halle of wich I seye
Testif they were and lusti to pleye
And onli for her mirthe ⁊and reuerye
Vpon the wardein besily they crie
To yeue hem leue but a litil stounde
To gon to melle and seen her corn̄ I grounde
And hardli they durst ley ther necke
The Millere shuld nat stele hem half a pecke
Of corne ne be force ne be sleiȝte hem reue
And ate last the wardein yaf hem leue
Iohn hiȝt that ⁊and Aleyn hiȝt that othir
Of oon toun̄ were they born þᵗat hiȝt Strother
Fer in the North I can nat telle where
This Aleyn maketh redy all his gere
And on an hors the sak he cast anon
Forth goth Aleyn and the Clerk also Iohn
With gode swerd ⁊and bokeler be his side
Iohn knewe the weye him neded no guide
And at the mylle the sak doun̄ he leith
Aleyn spak first al heill Symon̄ in feith
Hou fares thi fayre douȝter ⁊and thi wif
Aleyn welcome qduod Symkyn be my feith lif
And Iohn also hou now what do ye here
Be god quod Iohn Symon nede hath no pere
Him behoueth serue him self þᵗat hath no swain
Orellis he is a fooll as clerkes sain
Oure Manciple I hope he wil be ded
Swa werkes ay the wanges in his hed Caret mark between werkes and ay, but no correction.
And therefore am I come and eke Aleyn̄
To grynde oure corn̄ and carie it hom agein̄
I pray you spede vs that ye may
It shal be don ꝙquod Symon be my fay
What wol ye do whiles it is in hande
Be god riȝt be the hoper wil I stonde
Quod Iohn and se hou the corn̄ gos ynne
Yit sauȝ I neuer be my fader kynne
Hou that the hoper waggeth to and fro
Aleyn ansuerd Iohn wilt thou so
Than will I be by nethe by the corn̄
And se hou the mele falleth a doun̄
In to the trowe that shal be my disport
For Iohn in feith I may ben of your sort
I am as ille a Millere as ar ye
This Miller smyled of her nicete
And thouȝt al this nys but a wyle
They wene that noman may hem beguile
